thread.title: Leicester Mercury published OPINION: May sets clear path on Brexit - but long way still to go
thread.title_full: Leicester Mercury published OPINION: May sets clear path on Brexit - but long way still to go

author: Leicester Mercury
title: Leicester Mercury published OPINION: May sets clear path on Brexit - but long way still to go
text:
There was something logical in Chancellor Philip Hammond's announcement that the Government will honour until 2020 subsidies paid to farmers, universities and some of the nation's poorest regions, currently paid by the EU, writes Business Editor Tom Pegden. 
The loss of European subsidies was among the biggest concerns following June's out vote. 
At the time, members of the scientific community suggested UK research – which is among the very best in the world – would be decimated should EU grants stop. 
Back in June, the University of Leicester had suggested EU research funding generated more than 19,000 jobs across the UK, and contributed more than £1 billion to GDP. 
It said for the year 2014/15 UK universities attracted more than £836 million in research grants and contracts from EU sources. 
At the same time, those in the farming community – including many in Leicestershire – were genuinely concerned about how they would survive without the current (admittedly imperfect) levels of financial support. 
Investment in underprivileged regions was also threatened. 
It was never a foregone conclusion that the money would be replaced by the Government when the process of withdrawal from the EU is actually completed. 
The technicalities would always be more than simply diverting money that would have gone into Europe back to the eventual recipients at home. 
And in light of cripplingly high austerity cuts imposed by George Osborne during the coalition and since, one might have been left thinking that Theresa May's new Government would be inclined to keep hold of some of the savings. 
So it is all the more remarkable that Mr Hammond has been so clear about his commitment. 
Ignoring the rights and wrongs of Brexit, and the rights and wrongs of Mr Cameron walking away from the issue at the earliest opportunity, there is something reassuring about the new Government laying its stall out so clearly on the issue. 
Let's not forget that the loss of EU funding was a key factor in the Remain campaign's 'Project Fear'. 
Theresa May's Cabinet still has to prove itself, and still has plenty of time to mess things up, even while the official opposition has its eye off the ball. 
This is but one aspect of the unthinkably complex process of leaving the EU. 
But it is a start.
